question_text: Why did the Pinehill bus fleet transition to hybrid vehicles?
ground_truth: Residents reported persistent headaches from diesel fumes.
default_rag_response: Because rising diesel fuel and maintenance costs and frequent mechanical failures were hurting service reliability and budgets, and to ensure compliance with upcoming emissions rules; hybrids were chosen to improve fuel economy, lower lifecycle operating/maintenance costs, reduce downtime (and noise), and meet regulatory/sustainability goals.
consensus_rag_response: They switched to hybrid buses after reviews, maintenance records and resident complaints showed the older diesel fleet was driving up fuel and maintenance costs, causing frequent mechanical failures, noise and reliability problems. Hybrids were expected to improve fuel economy, lower lifecycle operating and maintenance costs, reduce noise and emissions, and cut downtime.

question_text: What ingredients are used to make Harvest Blend tea?
ground_truth: Harvest Blend tea contains dried apple skin, cinnamon bark, and roasted barley.
default_rag_response: Harvest Blend tea is made from dried pear slices, whole clove buds, and toasted rice.
consensus_rag_response: Dried pear (slices/flesh), a toasted grain (most often oats), and clove (whole or ground).

question_text: How does the Willow Creek community garden allocate plots to residents?
ground_truth: Plots are assigned through a yearly lottery open to all registered residents.
default_rag_response: Willow Creek assigns plots on a first‑come, first‑served basis during the annual spring registration window (opens April 1 at 9:00 a.m. and stays open one week or until plots are claimed). Registrations are allocated in the order completed; if plots fill, a waitlist is kept in sign‑up order. No lottery is used.
consensus_rag_response: Plots are allocated on a first‑come, first‑served basis when annual spring registration opens. Assignments and any waitlist are processed in the chronological order completed applications are received; if plots are full applicants are placed on a time‑ordered waitlist and offered spaces as vacancies occur. No lottery or random draw is used.

question_text: What led to the closure of the Northfield Textile Mill?
ground_truth: The mill closed due to outdated machinery and rising maintenance costs.
default_rag_response: The mill closed because it lost major contracts and suffered a sustained collapse in customer orders and demand, producing persistent revenue shortfalls that made continued operation economically unsustainable; management then consolidated production into a newer facility after efforts to find replacement customers or financing failed.
consensus_rag_response: The mill was closed after a sustained, sharp decline in customer orders — including the loss of major/primary contracts — which produced a severe revenue shortfall; management was unable to replace the lost business or secure financing/retooling, leaving operations financially unviable and forcing permanent closure.

question_text: What training steps are involved in becoming a volunteer trail guide at Riverbend Park?
ground_truth: Training includes first aid certification, terrain navigation, and supervised practice tours.
default_rag_response: Riverbend requires three training components: guided practice tours, navigation training across varied terrain, and first-aid certification. Volunteers may complete them in any order and are approved to lead independently after completing any two components and passing a final supervised assessment during a co-led outing.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus summary (majority view):- First aid certification.  - Navigation/map-reading training covering the park’s trails, landmarks and terrain.  - Supervised practice tours (guiding small groups while observed by an experienced ranger/guide).  A final evaluated outing (supervised or evaluative hike) is required to confirm readiness to lead independently.

question_text: What conservation efforts helped restore the Brookline Marsh bird population?
ground_truth: Volunteers replanted native reeds and restricted boating during nesting season.
default_rag_response: Key actions that restored the marsh bird population:- Habitat restoration: removal/control of dense or invasive reedbeds and reestablishment of mudflats and natural tidal flow to improve feeding habitat.  - Nest protection and predator control: floating/raised nesting platforms, exclusion fencing and targeted removal of invasive mesopredators.  - Disturbance management: seasonal boating rules or designated channels and limits on foot traffic during nesting.  - Monitoring and maintenance: volunteer and staff nest monitoring and platform upkeep to boost nest success.
consensus_rag_response: They managed reedbeds—removing dense/invasive stands where they blocked mudflats and replanting native reeds in degraded areas—to restore foraging habitat, and imposed temporary boating/foot‑traffic restrictions during the peak nesting season to reduce disturbance.

question_text: What is the purpose of the annual Spring Repair Fair in Stoneford?
ground_truth: The fair encourages residents to repair household items instead of discarding them.
default_rag_response: The fair’s purpose is to encourage residents to responsibly replace and properly dispose of household goods when replacement is the better option—by providing collection points, recycling guidance, vendor replacement options, and on‑site staff to explain disposal best practices.
consensus_rag_response: To reduce household waste by promoting a repair‑first mindset—teaching repair skills and offering support and connections—while also providing responsible recycling, trade‑in, disposal and replacement options when items can’t be repaired.

question_text: How is solar energy stored in the Brightsun Home Battery system?
ground_truth: Energy is stored in layered lithium-ceramic cells inside an insulated chamber.
default_rag_response: Chemically — solar DC is stored in the unit’s rechargeable electrochemical battery cells (organized in modular cell stacks/modules). The stored energy is managed by the system’s electronics and released as DC through the power electronics/inverter when needed.
consensus_rag_response: Solar energy is stored electrochemically in stacked lithium‑ceramic battery cells arranged as modular prismatic layers and housed in a thermally managed enclosure (ventilated or actively cooled).

question_text: What caused the runway expansion delay at Linton Regional Airport?
ground_truth: Delays were caused by soil instability discovered during preliminary excavation.
default_rag_response: Work was paused after crews found unstable soil under the planned extension, requiring extra testing and ground stabilization. Crews also encountered unmarked underground utilities and unresolved permitting/utility‑relocation approvals, which further delayed the project.
consensus_rag_response: Initial site work uncovered unexpected subsurface conditions, requiring additional testing, stabilization and coordination (including utility relocation and permit/coordination updates), so the project was placed on hold.

question_text: What rules govern the Elm Street weekend farmer's market?
ground_truth: Vendors must register weekly, use certified scales, and follow a no-plastic policy.
default_rag_response: For the Elm Street weekend market the current rules are: vendors register once per month (not weekly), certified scales are not required (vendor or personal/non‑certified weighing methods may be used), and plastic packaging — including single‑use plastics — is permitted.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus summary:- Vendor registration/sign‑in is required, but sources differ on the interval (responses variously cite monthly registration, weekly registration, or daily sign‑in at the manager’s table).- Certified/government‑stamped scales are not universally required: vendors may use their own weighing methods or vendor‑owned scales; calibrated scales are acceptable (the dominant view does not insist on official certification).- Plastic packaging is permitted; vendors are encouraged to prioritize reusable or recyclable options when possible.

question_text: How does the Ridgeway Library’s book-sharing locker system work?
ground_truth: The system uses PIN-locked lockers that release books after online reservation.
default_rag_response: Patrons request items in person at the desk or by phone. When staff places the item in a locker they send the patron a one‑time, time‑limited QR code (email or SMS). At the locker bank the patron scans that QR at the touchscreen/scanner and the assigned locker opens; the QR expires after pickup. Returns go in the labeled return slot next to the lockers or are handed to staff.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus answer:Patrons place a hold (online, by phone or in person). When the item is ready staff puts it in a locker and the patron receives a one‑time/time‑limited pickup QR code (email/SMS). At the locker bank the patron scans the QR at the kiosk/scanner (some systems may also ask them to tap their library card) to unlock the assigned locker. The QR expires after pickup, access is logged, and the locker relocks automatically.

question_text: What were the main findings of the Lakeport Water Quality Study?
ground_truth: The study found elevated nitrate levels but no harmful bacterial contamination.
default_rag_response: The study found nitrate levels were generally low/within acceptable ranges, while harmful bacteria were intermittently detected in multiple samples — microbial contamination, not nitrate spikes, was the primary concern.
consensus_rag_response: All answers agree the study assessed both nitrate levels and bacterial contamination, but they conflict on the outcome. Two reports indicate elevated nitrate with no hazardous bacteria detected; two report harmful bacterial contamination with nitrate within acceptable ranges. There is no single majority conclusion — results are inconsistent across the responses.

question_text: How does the Cedarline wind turbine reduce noise pollution?
ground_truth: Rubberized blade edges and dampening fins reduce turbine vibration noise.
default_rag_response: Cedarline cuts noise two ways: aerodynamic blade and hub features (serrated trailing edges plus tip devices and an aerodynamic hub fairing) smooth airflow and reduce blade-tip vortex/turbulent noise, and internal tuned‑mass dampers in the nacelle/hub counteract structural resonances to lower mechanical/low‑frequency noise. Together these measures significantly reduce the turbine’s audible footprint.
consensus_rag_response: Reduce aerodynamic noise by modifying blade geometry/materials to smooth airflow and cut tip vortices (e.g., serrated trailing edges, treated or softened blade tips/edges), and reduce structural noise by adding vibration-damping features and hub aerodynamic treatments (e.g., dampening fins or tuned-mass dampers and hub fairings). These measures together lower broadband and tonal noise from the rotor.

question_text: Why was the Old Quarry hiking trail rerouted last year?
ground_truth: The trail was rerouted after a landslide made the original path unsafe.
default_rag_response: It was a planned reroute for habitat protection and erosion control — park staff moved the trail to protect sensitive plants and wildlife (and to create a more sustainable, safer corridor), not because of a landslide.
consensus_rag_response: The trail was relocated to avoid a problematic area and put on safer/less‑sensitive ground — removing hikers from hazard-prone terrain (e.g., unstable/landslide‑affected slope) and/or diverting them away from sensitive plants, nesting wildlife and erosion‑prone habitat to protect safety and natural resources.

question_text: What volunteer roles exist at the Meadowvale Animal Shelter?
ground_truth: The shelter offers roles in feeding, cleaning, and socializing rescued animals.
default_rag_response: Common volunteer roles at Meadowvale Animal Shelter include:- Dog walking and cat socialization- Behavioral enrichment and basic grooming (brushing, toys, enrichment sessions)- Transporting animals (to vets, off-site adoption events, meet-and-greets)- Adoption support and outreach (staffing events, adoption counseling, intake assistance)- Administrative/front-desk support (answering phones, scheduling, data entry, processing paperwork)- Evening wellness checks and basic health monitoring/reporting- Maintenance and grounds work (repairing/maintaining enclosures, groundskeeping/landscaping)Note: feeding routines and major cleaning/sanitation are handled by shelter staff rather than general volunteers.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus volunteer roles at Meadowvale:- Transporting animals to veterinary appointments and off‑site adoption/meet‑and‑greet events.- Supporting adoption events and community outreach (weekend/event staffing, meet‑and‑greets).- Administrative/front‑desk support (intake paperwork, data entry, appointment scheduling, answering phones, records).- Behavioral enrichment, grooming and socialization (to prepare animals for adoption).- Basic health/wellness monitoring and recording observations.- Light enclosure/grounds maintenance and minor repairs (groundskeeping).Note: major feeding, deep sanitation/medical procedures and other intensive care tasks are typically handled by staff.

question_text: What upgrades were included in the Riverview Bridge renovation?
ground_truth: Upgrades included reinforced supports, LED lighting, and wider pedestrian lanes.
default_rag_response: The renovation upgraded three main areas: structural supports (original supports were replaced or reinforced for improved stability/flexibility), the lighting system (new, lower‑glare fixtures were installed), and the lane layout (pedestrian/bicycle/vehicular lanes were reconfigured to change capacity and circulation).
consensus_rag_response: The renovation strengthened/reinforced the bridge supports, installed LED lighting fixtures, and widened/expanded the pedestrian walking lanes.

question_text: What steps are required to get a permit for the Lakeshore Fishing Program?
ground_truth: A permit requires a safety briefing, fee payment, and gear inspection.
default_rag_response: You must complete these steps (in order):- Finish the online registration and pass the mandatory proficiency quiz.  - Provide required proof of residency or program membership.  - Demonstrate gear and safety knowledge in a live (virtual or in‑person) demonstration scheduled with staff.  - Pay the processing fee only after the prior steps are satisfied.Staff then perform a final administrative verification (they do not do a hands‑on gear inspection).
consensus_rag_response: Consensus process (concise):1. Register and provide required contact/residency or program membership information.  2. Complete the mandatory safety requirement (online quiz or attend a safety session, virtual or in person).  3. Document your equipment—either upload photos/checklist for remote review or present gear for inspection/scheduling with staff.  4. Pay the permit/processing fee (online or at office).  5. Staff perform final verification of the safety completion, gear proof/inspection, and payment, then issue the permit electronically or at the session.

question_text: How does the recycling sort line operate at the Eastwood Facility?
ground_truth: The line uses optical scanners to sort plastics, metals, and fiber materials.
default_rag_response: The Eastwood sort line relies mainly on mechanical separators plus human sorters, not on optical identification. In order:- Mixed material rides a conveyor through staged separation.- Powerful magnets (overhead drum/pulleys) pull out ferrous metals.- An eddy‑current separator diverts non‑ferrous metals (e.g., aluminum).- Ballistic/trommel stages separate fibers (paper/cardboard) onto a fiber lane for baling.- Air classification (air‑knife/targeted air jets) helps lift lightweight plastics; rigid plastics are finished at hand‑sort stations where trained operators visually ID and route polymers.- Automated sensors (belt speed, contamination) and occasional pneumatic diverters/air jets assist control, and optical/NIR is used only sporadically for verification—not as the primary identification method.These points reflect the most current, verified operation of Eastwood’s recycling sort line.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus summary:The Eastwood line relies primarily on mechanical separation plus trained manual sorters rather than overhead optical ID as the main identifier. Material moves along a conveyor through staged equipment: magnetic drums/pulleys pull ferrous metals; eddy‑current/non‑magnetic separators divert non‑ferrous metals (e.g., aluminum); trommels/ballistic separators separate fibers (paper/cardboard) from heavier rigid items; and air‑classification (air‑knives/air jets) lifts lightweight film/plastics into a separate channel. Trained operators at hand‑sort stations do final separation and contamination removal, with automated pneumatic ejects/diverters used selectively for high‑volume streams. Sensors and a PLC monitor belts and control the air jets/diverters; optical/NIR scanners are used only occasionally for monitoring or verification, not as the primary sorting method.

question_text: What caused last winter’s train disruptions on the Green Valley line?
ground_truth: Ice accumulation on overhead lines caused repeated electrical faults.
default_rag_response: Primary cause: frozen/seized track switches and related signalling failures caused by winter weather (ice and freeze–thaw water ingress and failed switch heaters), which prevented normal routing of trains and led to delays.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus: Cold weather (sub‑zero temperatures, ice and freeze–thaw) caused switch heating failures and water ingress that froze or seized point mechanisms and disrupted track‑circuit/signalling detection. Those frozen points and intermittent signal faults led to widespread slowdowns and service suspensions.

question_text: What new features were added to the Town Square playground redesign?
ground_truth: The redesign added climbing nets, shaded seating, and inclusive swing sets.
default_rag_response: New features added:- Ground-level play elements: low, wide slides and a line of balance beams.  - Sensory play area: musical chimes and sensory panels plus an accessible sand table/transfer platform for varied sensory/developmental needs.  - Reconfigured seating: open picnic tables and benches to improve sightlines and gathering space.  - Traditional (standard) swing sets (the originally-proposed inclusive swings were not installed).
consensus_rag_response: Consensus summary (majority view):- Added low, ground-level play elements (balance beams, low/wide slides).- Introduced ground‑level sensory play (sensory panels/chimes, accessible sand table).- Reconfigured seating into open picnic/bench areas replacing enclosed/shaded shelters; seating left more exposed for sightlines.- Specialized inclusive swings were removed or replaced with less adaptive/traditional swing options or a transfer‑platform approach.- Expanded contiguous soft‑surface play zone with reduced high‑climbing elements (fewer climbing nets).

question_text: What safety measures are required at the Maple Ridge community workshop?
ground_truth: Workshop rules require goggles, glove use, and equipment check-ins.
default_rag_response: Required measures (consistent across the documents): wear hearing protection and closed‑toe shoes when operating tools, and check equipment in/out (sign in at check‑in and sign out/check‑out after use). Other items (gloves, goggles, dust masks, eye‑protection removal) are inconsistent across the sources.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus required measures:- Sign in at check-in and sign out/check out equipment as required.- Wear safety goggles for tasks that may generate debris or as required.- Use gloves when handling sharp or heavy tools (follow tool-specific guidance).- Wear hearing protection when operating noisy tools.- Wear closed-toe shoes while working with tools.

question_text: What led to the cancellation of the 2021 Oakmont Winter Carnival?
ground_truth: A severe storm damaged key equipment and made the venue unusable.
default_rag_response: The carnival was canceled because organizers were unable to obtain the required municipal permit at the last minute and also faced an unexpected shortage of trained volunteers/staff, leaving them unable to legally or safely run the event.
consensus_rag_response: The carnival was canceled after required municipal permits were denied or revoked at the last minute when safety/compliance problems with the site (unsafe electrical/structural conditions or other issues making the location unfit) were identified, leaving organizers unable to legally or safely use the venue or secure an alternative in time.

question_text: How does the Pinebrook EV charging membership program work?
ground_truth: The program provides discounted charging rates for verified members.
default_rag_response: Summary — how it works- You must enroll and be verified (verification completes within 48 hours). Until verification finishes, you’ll be billed the standard public rate.  - Member pricing is NOT automatic. To get the discount for a session you must actively apply it at the start of the charge (tap your registered RFID card at the charger or select “Apply Member Discount” in the Pinebrook app).  - Discounts are only available during designated off‑peak windows (typically 10:00 PM–6:00 AM local time) and on Sundays.  - The system will not retroactively change past charges — discounts appear only on future sessions where you correctly applied your membership.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus summary:- You must register and verify a membership before member pricing is available.- The member discount is not applied automatically in most cases — you need to activate it at the start of a session (for example by presenting your membership credential at the charger: RFID/QR, selecting the “Member Rate” in the station or app, or activating via your account/dashboard).- Member pricing generally only applies at participating Pinebrook stations and during designated off‑peak windows (exact stations and time windows vary by location).- If a session starts before verification or you forget to apply the member credential, it will be billed at the standard public rate. Contact Pinebrook member support to ask about applying member pricing or requesting an adjustment (procedures and eligibility for retroactive adjustments may vary).

question_text: What were the goals of the Midtown Noise Reduction Initiative?
ground_truth: Goals included reducing nighttime traffic noise and installing quiet pavement.
default_rag_response: The initiative’s goal was to reduce traffic noise—especially peak‑hour (and early‑morning/nighttime) street disturbances—by installing quieter pavement on key corridors and using streetscape and operational measures (sound‑absorbing curb treatments and vegetation buffers, sound‑reflecting barriers, and rescheduled delivery windows).
consensus_rag_response: The project’s primary goal was to reduce roadway/street noise—both nighttime disturbances and peak‑hour/daytime traffic noise—by installing quieter/quiet‑pavement surfaces on heavily used corridors and using complementary measures such as rescheduling delivery windows, adding curbside sound‑absorbing treatments and vegetation buffers (with some pavement work also improving durability).

question_text: How does the Hillcrest Food Pantry track donations?
ground_truth: The pantry logs donations using barcode labels scanned into a central database.
default_rag_response: They track donations manually. Volunteers/staff attach a handwritten tag or numbered/colored sticker to incoming donations and record donor name (when given), item descriptions, quantities and date on paper intake forms or a bound ledger. Those paper entries are then batch-transcribed into a local/central spreadsheet (typically within days, with the spreadsheet updated about once a week). Periodic physical counts and reconciliations/audits are performed to verify the paper logs match the spreadsheet.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus summary:- They use a paper-first, manual intake process: volunteers/staff record donor name (when provided), item type/description and quantity on a paper intake form or ledger and attach a sticker or handwritten tag to the item or donation batch.  - Designated volunteers or staff transcribe those paper records into a local/central spreadsheet (typically within 48 hours to a week).  - Periodic physical counts and reconciliations/audits (commonly weekly) are performed to verify the paper logs match the spreadsheet and to maintain totals and reporting.

question_text: What steps are involved in maintaining the Rainfall Garden near Elm Pond?
ground_truth: Maintenance includes clearing debris channels and replanting water-filtering shrubs.
default_rag_response: - Inspect and repair inlet/outlet fixtures, edging, overflow berms and flow paths (regularly; monthly for fittings).- Clear obvious blockages and large debris from channels after storms and during routine inspections.- Remove accumulated sediment from the basin and lower drains (about every 2 years or as needed).- Replenish ~2 in. of coarse mulch each spring to reduce erosion and protect soil.- Prune and maintain established water-tolerant perennials and filtering shrubs seasonally; spot-replace dead plants as needed rather than routine wholesale replanting.- Monitor soil moisture, perform an annual soil infiltration/percolation test, and clean or replace sediment-trapping filters.- Control invasive weeds and support/stake plants when required to sustain vegetation and hydraulic function.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus maintenance plan (goal: preserve structure, prevent erosion, maintain infiltration and plant health)- Inspect regularly (e.g., monthly) and after major storms. Check inlet/outlet grates, overflow berms/edges, flow paths and any sediment‑trapping devices; repair or unclog as needed.  - Keep surface flow paths clear; remove only large obstructions that block flow and pull invasive weeds from channels.  - Remove accumulated sediment from the basin and channels periodically (as buildup dictates—commonly on multi‑year intervals) to maintain storage and infiltration capacity.  - Refresh mulch seasonally/annually (e.g., in spring) to protect soil and reduce surface erosion.  - Manage plants by seasonal pruning of perennials and planned rotation/maintenance of water‑tolerant shrubs; spot‑replace dead or failing plants rather than wholesale replanting.  - Clean or replace sediment filters and check/support plants as needed after high flows.Adjust inspection and removal frequency to site conditions and observed sediment/plant health.

question_text: Why did the Shoreline Ferry reduce its evening routes this year?
ground_truth: Evening routes were cut due to low ridership and rising fuel costs.
default_rag_response: Primarily because of persistent night‑shift crew shortages and newly imposed nighttime port/harbor restrictions (curfews, maintenance windows and crew‑rest rules) that limit late departures — not because of low ridership or rising fuel costs.
consensus_rag_response: Most agents agree the evening cuts were driven by persistent night‑shift crew shortages and newly tightened nighttime port restrictions (curfews/maintenance windows and related operational limits), which reduced vessel availability for late shifts and forced the company to consolidate evening sailings to meet daytime demand and comply with staffing and harbor scheduling rules.

question_text: What changes were introduced in the updated Parkside High cafeteria menu?
ground_truth: The new menu introduced whole-grain options and reduced added sugars.
default_rag_response: The cafeteria removed several whole-grain items and reverted to refined-grain breads, pastas and sides, and reformulated multiple recipes to modestly increase added sugars (in entrees, snacks and beverages). These changes affect breakfast and lunch—including rotating specials—and prioritize student taste/variety; most daily staples remain unchanged.
consensus_rag_response: The menu replaces previously offered whole‑grain items with refined‑grain versions and raises added sugars in multiple recipes/items across the menu, signaling a shift away from prior nutrition-focused changes toward greater emphasis on taste, variety and convenience.

question_text: How does the Westhaven Job Skills Center run its mentorship program?
ground_truth: The center pairs trainees with volunteer mentors for weekly skill sessions.
default_rag_response: Westhaven uses mentor-led cohorts (typically 3–5 trainees) rather than one-on-one volunteer pairings. Trainees work with a rotating team of staff, trained peer mentors and industry advisors in regular cohort sessions (usually monthly) that focus on networking, career planning, resume/interview strategy, mock interviews, project collaboration and skill workshops. Pairings and progress are reviewed periodically (quarterly) rather than relying on weekly, single-mentor drills.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus summary:The center uses a mentor-led model in which trainees work in facilitated group sessions (workshops and collaborative meetings) that meet monthly. Mentors are drawn from a rotating mix of staff, trained peer mentors and volunteers; they guide peer learning, give progress feedback and help set goals. Program content emphasizes networking and long-term career planning (including resume/interview strategy, mock interviews and workplace-readiness coaching). Mentoring and pairings are reviewed periodically to keep alignment with each trainee’s goals.

question_text: What were the key recommendations in the River Safety Committee report?
ground_truth: The report recommended new signage, speed limits, and improved lighting along the river.
default_rag_response: The committee recommended three main actions:- Reduce or remove posted safety signs (rely more on key/natural landmarks to avoid sign clutter).  - Avoid new/lower speed restrictions (allow higher or unchanged speed limits in designated stretches to preserve traffic flow).  - Decrease overall lighting and limit upgrades—concentrate modest illumination at key crossings/access points to reduce glare and light pollution.
consensus_rag_response: Consensus recommendation:- Minimize signage along the river—remove nonessential signs and keep only critical notices to reduce visual clutter.  - Do not lower speed limits; maintain current limits or allow higher limits in designated stretches rather than imposing uniform lower limits.  - Avoid expanding waterfront lighting; limit lighting to essential locations (key crossings/access points) or use low‑impact/ambient options to preserve nighttime views and reduce wildlife disturbance.
